conclusion: Identify the forces and constraints for bodies A, B, and C with given masses and friction coefficient.
Since bodies are at rest, net force on each body is zero; no friction between C and other bodies.
Body C experiences weight downward, normal forces from A, B, and ground.
For vertical equilibrium of C: N₃ = m·g - (N₁ sin θ₁ + N₂ sin θ₂).
Centers of hemispheres form an equilateral triangle; θ₁ = θ₂ = 30° = π/6 radians.
For horizontal equilibrium of C: N₁ cos θ₁ = N₂ cos θ₂, hence N₁ = N₂ = N.
For vertical equilibrium of C: N₃ = m·g - N.
For body A: weight downward, normal force from ground, friction force from ground, force from C at 30° above horizontal.
For horizontal equilibrium of A: f = N·(√3/2).
For vertical equilibrium of A: F = m·g - N·(1/2).
For body B: weight downward, normal force from ground, friction force from ground, force from C at 30° above horizontal.
For horizontal equilibrium of B: f₂ = N·(√3/2).
For vertical equilibrium of B: F₂ = 2m·g - N·(1/2).
Using friction coefficient: f = μ·F = (√3/6)·F and f₂ = μ·F₂ = (√3/6)·F₂.
Solve for N: N·(√3/2) = (√3/6)·F, hence N = F/3.
Substitute into vertical equilibrium for A: F = m·g - F/6, solving gives F = (6/7)·m·g.
Final answer: Normal force on A is F = (6/7)·m·g; frictional force is f = (√3/7)·m·g.
